4.1. FAs as target compounds

Fatty acids have been investigated as a target compound class to detect adulteration since the FA profile usually differs from one oil source to another. An increase in linolenic acid content in avocado, sesame and virgin olive oils was used to detect ad ulteration by addition of soybean oil [95, 96, 101, 102] . The higher le vel of erucic acid in olive oil, sesame oil and peanut oil can be taken as an indicator for adulteration with rapeseed oil [94, 102, 103] . The adulteration of olive oil w ith peanut oil can lead to higher content of eicosanoic, docosanoic and tetracosanoic acids, and saturated FAs [94]. High levels of palmitic acid in sesame oil can be regarded as adulteration with corn oil [101] .

Heidari et al. [100] analysed FAs after derivatisation to FAMEs to detect olive oil adulteration with lard using GC –MS. A non -polar column was applied due to its higher thermal stability. The addition of lard to olive oil increases the c ontent of saturated FAs such as palmitic, stearic and myristic acids; myristic acid is mainly present in lard, while it decreases the proportion of unsaturated FAs such as oleic acid.

The presence of trans -FAs in non -refined vegetable oils also may indicat e adulteration with refined oils. trans -FAs are not present in high concentration in crude vegetable oils. These FAs are usually formed during the refining process, arising from exposure to the high temperature applied in the deodorisation step. An increas e of trans -FAs isomers in EVOO was used to detect adulteration with cheaper refined oils [97].

Combining FA profiles of a target vegetable oil with chemometric analysis has been used to build methods to detect adulteration. Zh ang et al. [90] used GC –MS with SIM mode profiles of five vegetable oils (soybea n, rapeseed, sunflower, peanut and sesame oils) to detect adulteration. Applying multivariate statistical methods, identified FAs classified the five types of edible oils into five groups, to develop a model to simultaneously detect adulteration. The model was able to detect adulteration of edible oil with other vegetable oils at an adulteration level of 10% ( Fig. 4 ). Low abundant FAs were suggested to be more important for classification of the five types of edible oils, and additional parameters such as p hytosterols may be required to assess the authenticity of soybean oils.

Fig. 4. Scores plot between the first 2 principal components (PCs) for five types of edible oils and their blended/adulterated oils based on their FA profiles. 300 blended oils were simulated by mixing five oils with random proportions, while, 60 adulterated oils were simulated by blending 10% content of four other oils with random proportions to 90% soybean, peanut, sunflower, rapeseed, and sesame oils, respectively. Adapted from [90].

Xing et al. [102] studied a dulteration of sesame oil with other vegetable oils such as rapeseed, soybean, sunflower and maize oils, based on FA composition, applying discriminate analysis (DA) and PCA, as an effective qualitative adulteration tool. Partial least -squares regression ( PLSR) was successfully applied to quantitatively identify the type and the level of vegetable oil added to the sesame oil.

Although it is a relatively easy and somewhat satisfactory method for detecting vegetable oil adulteration, in many cases FA profile s do not generate reliable information about the authenticity of some vegetable oils that have similar FA composition. In these instances, detection of adulteration should target other classes of compounds [96, 101] .

4.2. Tocopherols and tocotrienols as target compounds Zhang et al. [20] proposed tocopherols and tocotrienols as being of great importance for indication of oil adulteration. Their study used GC –MS for simultaneous analysis of tocopherols and tocotrienols and found that most vegetable oils such as EVOO, sunflower, sesame, soybean, corn, peanut, r apeseed, palm and grapeseed oils have either no or low amounts of γ -tocotrienol whereas a high amount of γ -tocotrienol was detected only in palm oil. Thus, high amount of γ -tocotrienol may indicate adulteration of these oils with palm oil. Sesame oil conta ins an amount of α -tocopherol 20 –60 times lower when compared to the other oils, which may be used as a parameter to distinguish sesame oil adulteration.
4.3. Sterols as target compounds

Sterols comprise the major part of the unsaponifiable matter of vegetab le oils, and are recognised as being plant -specific. Sterol profiling plays a decisive role in classifying contamination of some vegetable oils, e.g., EVOO, with other cheaper ones. Jabeur et al. [96] reported an increase in campesterol and Δ7 -stigmastenol and decrease of the apparent β - sitosterol in EVOO adulterated with soybean oil; a higher level of campesterol and lower level of apparent β -sitosterol in EVOO adulterated with corn oil; and a higher level of Δ7 - stigmastenol in EVOO adulterated with sunflower oil. The addition of as little as 1% of sunflower oil to EVOO was reported to significantly increase the Δ7 -stigmastenol percentage. Research conducted on assessment o f EVOO authenticity also reported similar results; an increase in campesterol level indicated adulteration with soybean and corn oils; an increase in Δ7-stigmastenol suggested adulteration with soybean, canola and safflower oils [91]. Increases in campesterol and stigmasterol levels with decrease in β -sitosterol content were detected when avocado oil was adulterated with soybean oil [95].

Cholesterol has been investigated as a target compound to prove adulteration of plant oil with animal f at and/or waste cooking oil. This sterol is present in high concentration in animal fat, but it is usually low in vegetable oils [104, 105] . Zhao et al. [104] used GC –MS t o detect vegetable oil adulteration with waste cooking oil. Samples were analysed without derivatisation and with a non -polar column to provide good separation of target compounds. The content and ratio of cholesterol, β -sitosterol, and campesterol were us ed as a criterion for detection of vegetable oils adulterated with waste cooking oil. A large amount of cholesterol (>20 mg/kg) indicates adulteration, as do relative ratios of β -sitosterol, campesterol, and cholesterol in vegetable oils. The method proved to be accurate for detection of vegetable oils adulterated with 5% of refined waste cooking oil with 75 correct detections of adulteration out of 81 oil samples in multi -laboratory analysis. However, this method is only suitable to detect adulteration wit h waste cooking oil used for frying animal foods, not for frying non -animal foods.

Xu et al. [105] used sterols to detect virgi n coconut oil adulteration with animal fats, comparing 1DGC with GC×GC separation. Derivatisation to trimethylsilyl (TMS) ethers indicated incomplete separation of cholesterol from cholestenol for GC –FID and GC –MS analysis on a non -polar column. GC×GC anal ysis with the same non -polar column for 1D and a mid -polar 2D column improved resolution of the two compounds. Analysis by GC×GC – TOFMS was reported as a precise, reliable, and easy method to detect adulteration of virgin coconut oil with animal fats simply by assessing their cholesterol level. Virgin coconut oil adulteration with lard, chicken fat, mutton tallow, beef tallow, or their mixtures at a level as low as 0.25% could be determined.
4.4. Stigmastadiene as target compounds

A high content of stigmastadi ene is one of the most used target compounds to detect low level EVOO adulteration with refined oils. Stigmastadiene is formed during the refining process of edible oils by dehydration of β -sitosterol, and is quantified using GC‒MS after derivatisation [97, 106] . Tfouni et al. [98] showed the importance of stigmastadiene analysis for the detection of adulteration; therefore, FA, sterol and stigmastadiene c omposition were analysed in 70 EVOO samples. Nineteen samples were reported as adulterated and, among these, 14 samples showed all three parameters to be altered (FA, sterol and stigmastadiene composition), indicating the addition of an oil of a different vegetable origin. However, five samples did not present alteration in FA composition, so stigmastadiene analysis was necessary to detect the addition of refined oil. An unaltered FA composition indicated absence of vegetable oil from another source.

Srigle y et al. [91] noted the presence of Δ5,23 - stigmastadienol in refined olive oil, and blended EVOO with sunflower oil, and the absence of th is compound in pure EVOO analysis. Previous study detected presence of this compound in solvent -extracted olive oils [99].
4.5. VOCs as target compounds

Among the FA, TAG and VOC content, VOC proved to be the best marker compound class to detect adulteration in sesame oil with corn or soybean oils. The detection of 2 -propenal can discriminate between pure and adulterated sesame oils with 5% of corn or soyb ean oils [101] . Hu et al. [72] suggested VOC analysis to detect adulteration through application of HS GC×GC –TOFMS to identify VOCs in soybean, peanut, rapeseed and sunflower seed oils. Multivariate statistical methods were used to classify the four edible oils into four different groups. According to this study, 15 VOCs were selected as the most important compounds to classify edible oils and, therefore, used for identifying possible adulteration. The VOCs include 2-methyl -propanal , 3-methyl -butanal, 2 -methyl -butanal, camphene, 2,5 -dimethyl -pyrazine, 3 - nonen -2-one, 3 -methyl -2-butenal, cyclohexane, 2 -pentanone, 2 -hexenal, ( E,E)-2,4-nonadienal, 3-ethyl -2,5-dimethyl -pyrazine, 2 -n-butylfuran, 2 -furanmethanol and N-methylene - ethenamine.

Target VOCs for adulteration of sesame oil with soybean oil were analysed through HS SPME GC×GC –TOFMS. For this purpose, sesame oil, soybean oil and sesame oil adulterated with 5% of soybean oil were subjected to analysis. The SPME conditions were optimised and validated via central composite design and the chosen fibre DVB/CAR/PDMS was evaluated based on the number of retained compounds. The GC×GC –TOFMS analysis applied a non - polar × mid -polar column set. Twenty -five VOCs were selec ted to distinguish sesame oils and adulterated oils, with their concentrations found to be different in the two groups of oils, i.e., 25 VOCs can be used as markers to detect adulteration [107] . Zhao et al. [71] appli ed HS GC×GC –TOFMS (non -polar × mid -polar column set) to identify marker compounds in the pure oils, then to detect adulteration of sesame and peanut oils with soybean oil. Thirty common volatiles were identified in the pure oils and 31 compounds that are c rucial for flavour formation were selected from volatiles in different pure and adulterated oils as potential markers for PCA and CA. Adulteration of peanut oil and sesame oil with soybean oil at levels of 5 and 10% respectively were detectable.
5. Contaminants

Throughout the food supply chain, from farm -to-table, food can be exposed to various chemical contaminants. Example may include pesticides from raw material, hydrocarbons as a residual solvent or contaminant during pro cessing and logistics, mineral oil saturated (MOSH) and mineral oil aromatic (MOAH) hydrocarbon residues from fuel contamination, and alkylphenols or other migration contaminants from plastic packaging. GC‒MS is commonly used for such contaminant analysis, so brief comment will be made here.

Pesticides and related chemical treatments during food production, applied to crops to control various insect and biological stresses, are concerning issues worldwide, requiring residue measurement. GC is a highly sen sitive technique for pesticide detection [108] . GC –MS can be deployed as a generalist tool, where a whole range of compounds across many chemical classes can be detected with the availability of SIM mode or multiple reaction monitoring mode (MRM) in GC –MS/MS, for increased sensitivity and selectivity. Meanwhile GC hyphenated with nitrogen -phosphorous detection (NPD), flame photometric detection (FPD), or electron capture detection (ECD) is a spec ialist tool, and they are commonly used for organophosphorus pesticide or trace chlorinated compound detection in a wide range of food samples.

Apart from the detection method, an appropriate extraction technique is another important aspect to minimise int erference from the sample matrix. Different extraction methods have been developed over the years for pesticide detection in an oil matrix. Examples include low -temperature lipid precipitation [109] , dissociation extraction [110] , and QuEChERS [111] techniques. A study reported the appli cation of QuEChERS with GC –triple quadrupole MS (QQQMS, MRM mode) for the analysis of 255 pesticides in olive oil, peanut oil and soybean oil, with the LOQ range of 5 –50 μg/kg [112] . Hydrocarbons (MOSH, MOAH) can be in a form of a residual solvent or intrinsically formed during production [113] or as a result of the exposure to a contaminated source. Hydrocarbon contaminants may be analysed by HS GC –MS techniques [114] . HS SPME with GC –MS (SIM mode) was reported for the analysi s of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and xylene isomers (BTEX), alkylated monoaromatic hydrocarbon (C1 - to C4 -benzenes) and light polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs, up to four aromatic rings) in EVOO [115] . The LOD and LOQ values were in the range of 0.05–1.6 µg/kg and 0.2 –5.26 µg/kg, respectively. Interestingly, the reported values

incorporated distribution constant calculatio n, taking into account specific affinities of the SPME fibre for different compounds. An alternative method was reported for analysis of BTEX by using a thermal desorption unit (TDU) in combination with GC –MS (SIM mode) [116] . With this method, oil samples (corn, olive and sunflo wer oils) were placed inside a microvial insert, which were then introduced into a glass desorption tube. The whole tube was placed in the TDU unit. With the above set up, the study was shown to have a good detection limit of 0.7 –1.2 mg/L, and linearity ra nge of 10 –200 mg/L. Alkylphenols and bisphenol A are endocrine disrupting chemicals. Isotope dilution GC –MS was reported for the detection of bisphenol A, 4 -octylphenol, and 4 - nonylphenol in vegetable oils [117] . The samples were extracted by solid phase extraction and then derivatised with heptafluorobutyric anhydride prior to GC –MS (SIM mode) analysis with a non -polar column. LOD and LOQ were approximated to be 0.83 µg/kg and 2.5 µg/kg, respectively, with a recovery value of 64 –110%.

For a more comprehensive analysis of the contaminant, a method was developed for multiresidue analysis of PAHs, phthalate esters, and alkylphenols in edible vegetable oils [118] . Samples were extracted with hexane saturated acetonitrile, allowing the sample to be directly analysed (without derivatisation) by GC –QQQMS (MRM mode). The LOD and recovery values were 0.1 –4.0 µg/kg and 70.0 –110.8%, respectively.
6. Concluding remarks

Seed and vegetable oils are impor tant nutrients for human health. The composition of compounds in these oils ranges from major or bulk compounds, to trace components, and for various purposes, both the major and minor constituents are important analytically. In general, the analytical sep aration challenge can range from relatively straightforward, to very complex if the compounds are at trace level, constitute multiple chemical classes, and suffer matrix interference. While, single column GC –MS remains a popular choice for many components of the edible oil analysis due to its simplicity, and with the instrument being readily available in most laboratories and provides some measure of identification (e.g., retention index and MS library), multidimensional separations continue to be developed . The expectation of providing a comprehensive profiling of the oil sample, and the increased separation space provided allowing more compounds to be separated, is that improved identification will result, sometimes with improved LOD. Enhanced reliability of identification, and improved quantification increase the value of

the fingerprint that results, and can be usefully applied to identifying the plant oil origin, total composition, and assist in authenticity analysis with various compound classes employe d as markers. Increasing applications of GC×GC hyphenated with high resolution mass analysis in both MS and MS/MS mode are to be expected as a natural evolution of the field, to address oil quality and improved compound identification in future.

CAPÍTULO 3
Natural fractionation of tucuma (Astrocaryum vulgare Mart.) pulp olein to obtain crystallized lipids using a minimally processed, energy efficient process
Maria Fernanda S. Motaa, Meire Jéssica A. Ferreiraa, Fábio Júnior M. Novaesb,c, Philip J. Marriottd, Claudia Moraes de Rezendec e Suely P. Freitasa

aUniversidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Escola de Química, Av. Athos da Silveira Ramos, 149 - Bloco E - Cidade Universitária, Rio de Janeiro - RJ, bUniversidade Federal de Viçosa, Departamento de Química, Avenida Peter Henry Rolfs, s/n, Viç osa, MG 36570 -900, Brazil cUniversidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Instituto de Química, Laboratório de Análise de Aromas, Av. Athos da Silveira Ramos, 149 - Bloco A, 6º andar, Sala 626A - Cidade Universitária, Rio de Janeiro - RJ, 21044 -020, Brazil dAustralian Centre for Research on Separation Science, School of Chemistry, Monash University, Wellington Road, Clayton, VIC, 3800, Australia
Artigo submetido a Journal of Food Composition and Analysis

Abstract – A wide variety of native oleaginous fruits, rich in unsaponifiable compounds, including antioxidants of interest to the food, cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries, is available in Brazil. Among these fruits, tucuma ( Astrocaryum vulgare Mart.) oil is o f particular interest as it is rich in antioxidants and monounsaturated fatty acids, extracted from the tucuma pulp. This work evaluated the fractionation of tucuma olein by natural crystallization over 2 and 7 days. There was no significant difference in the mass percentage of phase formation between the 2nd and 7th day of cooling. The super olein fraction had a higher β -carotene content per g of oil than the olein and the tucuma mid - fraction. All fractions presented oleic fatty acid as a major component and triacylglycerols with 52 and 54 carbon atoms, with a predominance of two uns aturated acyl chains and fully unsaturated triacylglycerols. The tucuma mid -fraction showed characteristics of a pseudoplastic fluid behavior and pseudo -β' crystals desired for food formulation, similar to palm stearin and palm mid -fraction. Therefore, tuc uma mid -fraction has potential application in the food industry to replace palm and trans -fat oils.
Keywords : Crystallization; Olein; Stearin; Palm mid -fraction; Oleic acid; Carotenoids; Palm oil substitute; R heology .
1. Introduction

Palm oil has become th e largest edible oil consumed globally for food and industrial use since 2004 (USDA, 2007; USDA, 2021) . In the food industry, this oil plays a vital role in replacing hydrogenated oils with trans -fatty acids that are nutritionally undesirable since their intake is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. The use of oils with t-fatty acids in the food industry has steadily decreased since the mid -90s and the World Health Organization (WHO) released an action package aiming to eliminate industrially -produced t-fat globally by 2023 (Valenzuela et al., 1995; Gunstone, 2002; Hinrichsen, 2016; WHO, 2021) .

Palm oil is a suitable replacement for hydrogenated oils due to its chemical composition that permits the oil to be fractionated in multiple stages, generating fractions with a wide range of functional melting profiles (Gunstone, 200 2; Kellens et al., 2007; Hinrichsen, 2016) . Fractionation is a reversible process of lipid modification used to separate, by crystallization, the original oil in two or more fractions with different physical and/or chemical properties (Himawan et al., 2006; Sato, 2018) . Depending on the molecular structure, lipid composition, chain length and degree of unsaturation, as the cooling path proceeds from the vegetable oil in its liquid state, triglycerides can form different crystal structures (polymorphism) (Himawan et al., 2006; Sato, 2018) . The three most common crystalline forms in oils are α, β', and β. The α polymorph is the least stable form; in thi s case, the triglycerides crystallize in a hexagonal structure. In the β' polymorph, the triglycerides are packed in the orthorhombic form, and this polymorph is essential for

margarine making and shortening. The most stable crystalline form is β, where th e triglycerides crystallize in a triclinic structure (Gunstone, 2002; Sato, 2018) . The first palm fractionation generates a lighter phase called olein, mainly used as dee p- frying oil, and a heavier phase (stearin) used for vanaspati. The olein fractionation generates the super olein , lighter phase used as salad oil , and the palm mid -fraction , which is widely used as cocoa butter extenders and for shortenings and margarine production (Kellens et al., 2007; Jin et al., 2018) . However, the nutritional value of palm oil is questioned since it presents a high content of saturated fatty acids (FAs), associated with an increase in the concentration of low -density lipoprotein (LDL), and a consequential increased risk of cardiovascular disease. Moreover, the cultivation of palm trees is frequently correlated with poor sustainability practices due to problems related to the destruction of tropical forests and the extinction of native species. These factors have led to a growing interest in substitutes for palm oil as a more nutritious and sustainable oil, and food products free of palm oil without regressing to t-fat oils (Hinrichsen, 2016) . Tucuma is a native palm tree from the north of South Americ a, known for its spontaneous and natural regeneration. Tucuma exploitation is carried out sustainably by small local producers organised in Brazilian cooperatives in the Amazon region following agroforestry management practices. Development of a production chain of by -products of tucuma oil is a strategic opportunity for sustainable development in traditional Amazonian communities, offering improvements in family income, and encouraging conservation of forest and local biodiversity. Benefits include reducti on of fires and reduced deforestation for the growth of non -native species, cattle production, land alienation and illegal economic activities (e.g. wood and ores) (Lima et al., 2014; Fasciotti et al., 2020) . The tucuma fruit has a high concentration of lipids both in the pulp (40 - 75%) and in the kernel (approximately 40%). The tucuma pulp oil is rich in bioactive compounds and unsaturated FAs (45 - 70%); however, the kernel extract is fat -rich in saturated FAs (around 85%) (Mambrim & Barrera -Arellano, 1997; Bora et al., 2001; Ferreira et al., 2008) .

The edible oil extracted from the tucuma pulp tastes pleasant with a unique aroma , besides being rich in bioactive compounds, especially carotenoids (Chiu et al., 2009; Santos et al., 2013b, 2015) . Tucuma oil carote noid content (about 1200 mg /kg) is, in general, higher than palm oil (about 580 mg/kg), buriti oil (about 540 mg/kg) and pupunha oil (about 355 mg/kg) (Department of Standards Malaysia, 2007a; Santos et al., 2015) . The high content of carotenoids suggests considerable nut ritional and functional potential with health benefits such as immunomodulation, provitamin A activity and reduction in the risk of developing chronic diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular disease, cataracts and macular degeneration (Rodriguez -Amaya et al., 2008; Ribeiro et al., 2011) .

The tucuma pulp oil FA composition comprises a large amount of oleic acid (45 - 70%) and a relatively low amount of saturated FAs (25 - 30%) when compared to palm oil, with palmitic fatty acid being the second most abundant FA (Mambrim & Barrera -Arellano, 1997; Bora et al., 2001; Ferreira et al., 2008; Rodrigues et al., 2009; Santos et al., 2013a) .

Unlike saturated FAs, monounsaturated FAs, such as oleic acid (ω9), have been highlighted for th eir benefits to human health. Oleic acid has been reported to have beneficial effects on the immune response, especially in autoimmune diseases and cardiovascular disease ( Sales -Campos et al., 2013) . In addition to nutritional aspects, this fatty acid has high oxidative stability, which enables its use in industrial products (O’ In this context, the use of tucuma oil to obtain crystallized lipids by natural fractionation is relevant to encourage sustainable exploitation of tucuma tree and develop a production chain of by -products from the edible oil. Natural fractionation of tucum a oil can be carried out simply by temperature, without either agitation or use of a reactor. Thus, it can be carried out by local cooperatives in the Amazon region offering a cheap, sustainable, easy, minimal processing and energy efficient process. This work performed tucuma pulp olein natural fractionation, to obtain two phases with different industrial applications i.e. as salad oil and margarine manufacture. The study investigates the physical, chemical and rheological characteristics of the tucuma ole in and the fractions obtained from this phase.
2. Materials and Methods
2.1. Sample and standards

The tucuma pulp oil was extracted by mechanical pressing on a commercial scale in Ananindeua -PA, Brazil. The crude oil was initially submitted to decantation in a B echer capped with plastic film protected from light for 30 days at room temperature (25 °C) to separate the acid olein (liquid phase) from the sludge (solid phase). The acid olein was deacidified for the fractionation experiments by liquid -liquid extractio n according to the methodology developed by Ferreira et al. (2021) until its free FA content was reduced to 3.4 - 6.80 mg KOH /g of oil. The deacidification was performed in two stages using an ethanol/water solution at 94 °GL in a 2:1 (w/w) solvent/oil ratio in an orbital shaker (Dubnoff PT 100, Nova Instruments Equipamentos para Laboratórios Ltda., Piracicaba, SP, Brazil ) at 30 °C and 150 rpm for 10 min. The phases separation was carried out in a settling funnel at room temperature (25 °C) for 30 min and 60 min in the first and second stage s, respectively.

A triacylglycerol (TAG) standard of tripalmitin (PPP), tristearin (SSS), triolein (OOO), trilinolein (LLL), trilinolenin (LnLnLn) and triarachidin (AAA) (Nu -Chek Prep, Inc., Elysian, MN) at a concentration of 600 ppm in hexane; and 1,2 -palmitin -3-olein (PPO), 1,2-olein -3-linolein (OOL), 1 -2-olein -3-palmitin (OOP), 1,2 - linolein -3-palmitin (LLP) and 1,2 -olein -3-archidin (OOA) (Larodan AB, Solna, Sweden) at a concentration of 1000 ppm in hexane was used as a TAG reference standard. Abbreviat ions are P ( palmitic; C16:0), S (stearic; C18:0) , O ( oleic; C18:1) , L (linoleic; C18:2) , Mg (mangiferic; 9,15 - octadecadienoic acid; C18:2), Ln ( linolenic; C18:3), and A (arachidic; C20:0). The FAME standard mixtures ( n-C14-C22) was used as FAME reference standard (Supelco, Bellefonte, PA). The carotenoid standards β -carotene, 13 -cis-β-carotene and 9 -cis-β-
carotene was used as carotenoid reference standard (Sigma -Aldrich Corporation, San Luis, MO).
2.2. Fractionation

Olein fractionation was performed by batch crystallization in triplicate using a refrigerated incubator (Nova Instruments 1704, Nova Instruments Equipamentos para Laboratórios Ltda.). Before the cooling tests, the olein was heated in a water bath at 45 ± 3 °C to lose the memory of crystals .

Natural fractionation tests were performed in triplicate using 50 mL centrifuge tubes with identical conical shapes containing 20 ± 0.5 g of tucuma olein. The crystallization was carried out isothermally at a temperature range between 9 - 13 °C for both 2 and 7 days. In natural cooling crystallization, long residence times of around 2 or 3 days are required (de Castro et al., 2019) , however, the en ergy required is smaller than in forced cooling crystallization. This temperature range permits the formation of an upper phase called super olein, and a heavier phase called the tucuma mid -fraction. Phase separation was carried out by filtration at the cr ystallization temperature. Fig. 1 illustrates the oil processing and olein fractionation scheme.
Fig. 1. Flow chart of the tucuma oil processing and natural fractionation of the olein fraction.

2.3. Free fatty acid content The free FA content was determined by titration in triplicate according to method 2.201 (IUPAC, 1992) . The analysis was carried out adding 2.0 g of sample in a 50 mL Tucuma Crude Oil Decantation SludgeAcid Olein Deacidification Olein Natural Fractionation Tucuma Mid-FractionSuper Olein

Erlenmeyer with 20 mL of diet hyl ether: ethanol (1:2 v/v) solution and about 2 -3 drops of phenolphthalein 1%. The sample was titrated with 0.1 N NaOH solution under continuous stirring until the pink color was observed. The free fatty acid content was calculated by using the following equation:
where V represents the volume of NaOH used for titration in mL, N the normality of NaOH solution, and m the sample mass in gr ams.
2.4. Quantification of unsaponifiable matter

The determination of the unsaponifiable matter content was carried out according to Hartman et al. (1994) using petroleum ether instead of cyclohexane. The analysis was performed in triplicate. In a 100 mL flat -bottomed flask, 2.5 g of sample were weighed and mixed with 10 mL of 95% ethanol and 2 mL of 50% KOH solution (w/v). The mixt ure was refluxed for 30 min and then transferred to a settling funnel. To the mixture, 50 mL of petroleum ether and 25 mL of 50% ethanol were added, shaken and separated. The lower phase was collected and washed again in two stages using, respectively, 25 mL of petroleum ether and 10 mL of 50% ethanol and 20 mL of petroleum ether and 20 mL of 50% ethanol. The three upper phases were mixed and washed with 25 mL of distilled water. The upper phase was dried with magnesium sulfate and weighed after solvent evaporation. The unsaponifiable matter was calculated by using the following equation: where m1 represents the sample mass in grams and m2 the mass in grams of the upp er phase after solvent evaporation.
2.5. Quantification of carotenoids

The total carotenoids content was determined by spectrophotometry (UV -1800, Shimadzu Corporation, Kyoto, Japan); the sample was diluted using petroleum ether and the absorbance at 450 nm wa s used for the calculation of total carotenoids according to the following equation (Rodriguez -Amaya, 2016) .
where ABS represents value of absorbance at 450 nm, V the sample volume and m the sample mass in grams.

The content of β-carotene, 13 -cis-β-carotene and 9 -cis-β-carotene was determined according to Pacheco et al. (2014) using a Waters modular high -performance liquid chromatograph (HPLC, Waters Corporation, Milford, Massachusetts, USA) comprising a model 600 pump, model 717 plus injector, model 996 photodiode array de tector (PDA)

and Empower software. The column used was a YCM Carotenoid S -3 (4.6 × 250 mm), held at a temperature of 33 °C, the injection volume was 15 μL, with gradient elution mode. The mobile phase used was methanol (Phase A) and t-butyl methyl ether (Phase B) at a flow of 0.8 mL /min. Analysis time was 28 min. The elution started with 80% methanol and 20% t-butyl methyl ether. At 0.5 min the t-butyl methyl ether was increased to 25%, at 15 min to 85% and at 15.05 to 90%, and held until 16.50 min. At 16.55 min the t-butyl methyl ether was returned to 20% and remained constant until 28 min. Carotenoids were identified based on the standards retention times. The analysis was performed in duplicate. The quantitative composition was determined by area normalization and correlated with the total carotenoids obtained by spectrophotometry according to the following equation.
Where t he % compound represents the area percentage of the carotenoid compound identified.
2.6. X-ray diffraction

The analysis of the polymorph present in the tucuma mid -fraction was performed by X - Ray Diffraction in a Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer (Rigaku Corporati on, Tokyo, Japan). CuK α radiation ( λ=0.15418 nm; 40 kV and 20 mA) was used, and data acquisition was performed with a step of 0.02 between 2 θ = 5 - 80°. The characteristic short spacing was calculated using the Bragg Law to identify the crystalline form.
2.7. Rheological analysis

The rheology behavior of the oils and their fractions was performed by a rotational test on the Anton Paar Physica MCR 501 rheometer (Anton Paar GmbH, Graz, Austria) at a shear rate range of 0 -600 1/s using 50 mm diameter cone -plate g eometry (CP50 -1). The analyses were performed at 10 °C, 20 °C and 30 °C. The rheological model of Power law was used to investigate the flow behavior of tucuma olein, super olein and mid -fraction.
2.8. Fatty acids profile and iodine value

The FA methyl esters (FAMEs) were determined according to Ce 1a -13 method (AOCS, 2004) . The FAMEs were prepared foll owing the procedure reported by Hartman & Lago (1973) . The analysis was carried out by mixing 0.5 g of sample with 5 mL of 0.5 N methanolic potassium hydroxide. After refluxing for 4 min, 15 mL of a solution of sulfuric acid in methanol and ammonium chloride was added. The mixture was refluxe d for 3 min and then transferred to a settling funnel. To the mixture, 25 mL of petroleum ether and 50 mL of distilled water were added, shaken and separated. The lower phase was collected and washed again with two portions of 25 mL of petroleum ether. Th e three upper phases were mixed and washed with 25 mL of distilled water. The upper phase was dried with magnesium sulfate and, after solvent evaporation, 20 µL was mixed

with 980 µL of hexane for the chromatography analyses . Chromatography analyses were carried out in triplicate using an Agilent 6890 gas chromatograph (GC) (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) equipped with an automatic injector coupled to a flame ionization detector (FID). The GC -FID conditions were as follows: capillary column DB -Wax (polyethylene glycol, Agilent J&W, Santa Clara, CA ) of 30 m length, 0.25 mm inner diameter (ID), and 0.25 μm film thickness ( df). Operating conditions: detector temperature 260 °C; injector with split flow at 230 °C; oven temperature of 160 240 °C for 10 min. Hydrogen was used as carrier gas at 0.3 mL/min; volume injected was 1 μL, with split ratio 1:20. The qualitative composition was determined by comparing the peak retention times with the respective FAME standard mixtures and by GC -MS analysis under the same chromatographic conditions. The semi quantitative composition was determined by area normalization and expressed as a mass percentage , of interest here is the relative proportions of the different FAME isomers, and in particular the unsaturated content and the chain lengths. Hence, the absolute composition of each FAME is not required. The GC -FID response is known to be linear with concentration, and for the purposes of this study, isomer composition will be sufficiently close to their relative responses.

2.10. Triacylglycerols analysis

The samples analyzed by GC -FID and GC -MS were in a concentration of ca. 0.5 % w/v in hexane. The TAGs analysis was carried out in triplicate using an Agilent 7890A GC (Agilent Technologies) equipped with an automatic injector and a FID, using a DB -5ms column ( Agilent J&W) of 20 m length, 0.25 mm ID and 0.10 μm df. Operating conditions: detector temperature 350 °C; injector with split flow at 300 °C; oven temperature 300 °C, then 300 to 340 °C (at 1 °C /min), hold at 340 °C for 2 min; hydrogen was used as the carrier gas at 2.0 mL/min; volume injected was 1 μL, split ratio 1:50. The semi quantitative composition was determined by area normalization a nd expressed as a mass percentage according to the carbon number of the components associated with each peak group determined by comparing the peak retention times with the reference TAG standards. The TAG analysis was also performed in duplicate using an Agilent 7890A GC coupled to an Agilent (5975C Series) quadrupole mass spectrometer (qMS) with similar conditions to those used above. Oven temperature 300 °C, then 300 to 350 °C (at 1 °C/min); helium was used as carrier gas at 1.5 mL/min. The full scan mod e data acquisition was over the range 50 to 700 m/z, with electron ionization (EI) at 70 eV, source temperature of 230 °C and a transfer line temperature of 300 °C. The fragment ions [M –RCO 2]+, [RCO+128]+, [RCO+74]+ and RCO+ presented in Table 1 where R is the aliphatic hydrocarbon chain, were used for tentative identification of the TAGs in the analysis, (Ruiz -Samblás et al. , 2010; Waktola et al., 2019) . Statistical analyses were performed using the means -comparison test (Fisher -LSD), considering a 95% confidence interval (p <0.05).
3. Results and Discussion
3.1. Fractionation and unsaponifiable matter

The unsaponifiable matter content of tucuma olein obtained b y pressing was 0.54 ± 0.05%, a value lower than that reported for tucuma oil extracted with hexane (2.2%) and diethyl ether (1.8%) (Mambrim & Barrera -Arellano, 1997; Santos et al., 2013b) . This difference is possibly due to the deacidification step conducted with 94 °GL ethanol, which leads to a migration of t hese compounds to the hydroethanolic phase (Ferreira et al., 2021) . Furthermore, the unsaponifiable matter varies according to weather conditions, degree of ripeness of the fruit, and the oil extraction; the use of an apolar solvent may favor migration of the unsaponifiable fraction to the oil when compared with oils extracted by pressing (Rodriguez -Amaya et al., 2008; Ferreira et al., 2021) . Table 2 shows the mass percentage of super olein and mid -fraction obtained in the natural fractionation of tucuma olein after 2 and 7 days, as well as the unsaponifiable matter of each fraction. Natural crystallisation usually requires a long period of time to allow a visually clear phase separation. Two days was sufficient to reach a visual separa tion. Seven days of cooling has previously been used for olive oil fractionation (Jansen & Birch, 2009) and this fractionation time was also performed to assess if a longer fractionation period would impact significa ntly on the phase formation, the unsapon ifiable matter distribution and/or the melting temperature of the crystals. Table 2. Mass percentage of phase formation and unsaponifiable matter of the phases obtained from the natural fractionation of the tucuma olein after 2 and 7 days. Phases Days Mass percentage of phase formation (%) Unsaponifiable matter Super olein 2 65 a 0.51 a Tucuma mid - fraction 2 35 b 0.69 a Different letters in the same column represent significantly different values (p<0.05). There was no significant difference in the mass percentage of phase formation between the 2nd and 7th day of cooling regarding the fractionation. Furthermore, in all tests, no significant differences were observed concerning the unsaponifiable matter content of all fractions. Additionally, both tucuma mid -fraction obtained after 2 and 7 days melted at 30 °C in less than 5 min. Therefore, it was decided to proceed with the fractionation after 2 days.
The unsaponifiable matter content of tucuma ol ein, super olein and mid -fraction was higher than commercial crude palm oil (0.19 - 0.44%), and it is in the range of commercial
palm olein (0.30 - 1.30%) (Department of Standards Ma laysia, 2007a, 2007b) .
3.2. Rheological and DRX analysis

The crystal structure formed by lipids has a significant impact on food products rich in fat (such as margarine and chocolate); many physical and sensory attributes (such as spreadability, texture and mouthfeel) are dependent on the rheological properties of the crystal network formed by the lipids (Narine & Marangoni, 1 999; Higaki et al., 2004; Normah et al., 2013) . The crystal structure can be determined by the spacing between the crystals calculated from the DRX analysis. The α polymorph is characterized by a crystal spacing of 4.15 Å, β' by a spacing of 3.80 and 4. 20 Å and β by a spacing of 4.6 Å (Kalnin et al., 2005; Szydłowska -Czerniak et al., 2005; Zhang et al., 2014) . The tucuma mid - fraction presented a spacing between the crystals of 4.40 Å, a spacing specific to the pseudo -β' polymorph , a polymorph with a pseudo -orthorhombic structure and a melting point temperature higher than β’ (Kalnin et al., 2005; Lee et al., 2008) .

The β' polymorph is present in margarine and spreadable products since they are metastable, form relatively small crystals, and incorporate a large amo unt of water droplets and semi -solid oil within the crystalline network (Sato, 2018) . Sato (2018) points out the tendency to form stable β' crystals as a requirement for the oil to be considered an alternative to trans -fat, which proves the potential of the tucuma mid -fraction to be used in food formulation. The tendency for the formation of the β' type polymorph in tucuma oil was reported by Oboh & Oderinde (1988) , since the tucuma pulp oil presents a high amount of palmitic moiety and 21.2% of this FA is in the position sn-2 of the TAG. Oils with a moderate to a high amount of palmitic moiety at the sn-2 position of the TAG generally exhibit β'-type crystallization.

Palm oil and stearin also present the crystal habit β'; this crystallization behavior ensures its applications in margarine, spreads, general -purpose shortenings and confectionery fats. However, palm oil and palm stearin present a lower β' crystal stabilit y when compared to the hydrogenated oils. Hence, products based on palm oil and its fractions may go through a undesirable polymorphic transition during storage leading to problems related to hardness, sandiness texture, and low spreadability (Oboh & Oderinde, 1988; Yap et al., 1989; Ribeiro et al., 2015; Zaliha et al., 2018) .

The rheological analysis was carried out at different temperatures to evaluate the potential of industrial application of tucuma olein, super olein, and mid -fraction. The rheological behavior indicated that the tucuma mid -fraction viscosity decays with increasing shear rate up to 10 1/s, characterizing this fraction as a pseudoplastic fluid at all temperatures (Fig. 2). From 10 1/s, the viscosity remained nearly constan t, and the fluid exhibits a Newtonian behavior. The crystalline arrangement formed by TAGs confers this rheological characteristic, desired in the food industry for manufacturing a wide range of products and present in products like ice creams, nut creams and shortenings (Karaca et al., 2009; Abdul Azis et al., 2011; Glicerina et al., 2013; Ay demir, 2019) . Tucuma olein and super olein also exhibited pseudoplastic fluid behavior at 10 °C due to crystal

formation at this temperature. However, in assays at 20 °C and 30 °C, the viscosity remained nearly constant with the increase in the shear ra te confirming the absence of crystals in the medium (Fig. 2).

Fig. 2. Tucuma mid -fraction, super olein and olein rheological behaviour at ( A) 10 °C; The model parameters, consistency index (K) and flow behavior index (n), presented in Table 3, were estimated by linear fitting of the data to the power law model. The regression coefficients (R2) for the model were higher than 0.98 for all fractions at the three evaluated temperatures. The “n” paramete rs indicate the level of deviation from a Newtonian fluid; considering that a Newtonian fluid has an “n” value of 1, n<1 indicates a pseudoplastic behavior and n>1 a dilatant behavior. The "K" value is related to the viscous nature of the sample; thus, a h igher “K” value indicates a higher resistance to flow.

Tucuma mid- fraction Super olein Olein Tucuma mid- fraction Super olein Olein Tucuma mid- fraction Super olein Olein In tucuma olein and super olein, the values calculated for parameter "n" at 20 °C and 30 °C were very close to 1, having the same flow characteristic as a Newtonian fluid (Table 3). However, at 10 °C, the value of "n" was much less than 1 due to the formation of crystals during the tests. At 10 °C, tucuma olein an d super olein also had a much higher “K” value than the values obtained at 20 and 30 °C, since the presence of crystals increases the apparent viscosity of the fluid and the resistance to flow at low shear stress (Kellens et al., 2007; Su & Lannes, 2012) . However, at 10 °C the "K" value of the tucuma olein and super olein were lower than the mid -fraction value, possibly due to the higher number of crystals in the mid -fraction that increases the viscosity of this phase. The rheological flow behavior of the tucuma olein and super olein is similar to that reported for olive oil at 20 °C and 30 °C , which presented a Newtonian fluid behavior and show ed an "n" value of 0.9 at both temperatures, a "K" value of 0.07 (Pa ·s)n at 20 °C and 0.05 (Pa ·s)n at 30 °C. However, at 10 °C the olive oil remains as a Newtonian fluid, unlike the tucuma olein and super olein (Punia et al., 2020) . The similar “K” value of the tucuma olein and super olein when compar ed to olive oil at 20 and 30 °C shows the proper consistency of these tucuma fractions to be used as cooking and salad oil. The tucuma mid -fraction had an "n" value inferior to 0.5 at all assay temperatures. As expected, this value increases as temperature increases, mainly due to crystal destabilization above 30 °C. The consistency index (K) also confirmed this behavior since this value decreases as the temperature increase, reflecting the decrease of the viscosity that can be noted visually. When the tucuma mid -fraction is stored under 10 °C, this phase behaved as a solid; between 15 °C and 25 °C, it as a fluid gel. This therm al behavior occurred, probably, due to the presence of the β' crystals that remain stable in this temperature range. Above 30 °C, the crystals disappear in approximately 5 min, and the mid-fraction is fully melted; therefore, the crystals present in the tu cuma mid -fraction are stable until 30 °C, and also, the fluid gel behavior above 10 °C indicates that this fraction shows good spreadability at room temperature. Regardless of temperature, deformation

rate values above 10 1/s promoted solubilization of the crystals for all samples, which approximates all samples’ rheological behavior to that of a Newtonian fluid. The crystallization process is the arrangement of the system by physical interactions between TAG molecules. This phenomenon is quite complex, as it usually occurs from a liquid phase composed of substances with different physical and/or chemical properties and occurs due to successive stages: supercooling of the liquid oil, nucleation, crystal growth and crystal aggregation. As the solid fraction increases, the viscosity of the medium increases, not only due to crystal growth but also due to crystal size distribution and interactions between crystals (Himawan et al., 2006; Kellens et al., 2007) .
3.3. Chemical characterization

The chemical characterization, such as carotenoid content, FA, and TAG composition, directly influences the potential industrial application, crystallization characteristics, and quality of the tucuma olein, super olein and mid -fraction. Carotenoids are antioxidant compounds recognized for promoting human health benefits such as reducing the risk of contracting chronic degenerative diseases, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, neurodegeneration, cataracts and macular degeneration (Rodriguez -Amaya, 2016) . Therefore, the high concentration of this compound increases the functionality of the oil, and it is desired for food application as salad oil, cooking oil and functional foods. The analyzed olein (Table 4) has a value below those reported for tucuma oil (~135 µg /g to ~567 µg/g) (Oboh & Oderinde, 1988; Santos et al., 2015) and for palm oil (474 - 689 µg/g) (Department of Standards Malaysia, 2007a) ; this smaller amount is due to the deacidification step used to reduce the values of free FAs, causing losses of s ignificant amounts of carotenoids (Ferreira et al., 2021) .
Table 4. Content of β-carotene, 9 -cis-β-carotene, 13 -cis-β-carotene and total carotenoids of tucuma olein, super olein and mid -fraction.
Olein Super olein Tucuma mid - fraction 9-cis β-carotene 13-cis β -carotene ND: not detected.

The β -carotene fractionation was efficient using the selected conditions, giving a super olein with a β -carotene concentration 11 times higher than the tucuma mid -fraction. The 9-cis-β-carotene and 13 -cis-β-carotene contents were also higher in super olein when compared to olein and the mid-fraction. The distribution of carotenoids to the super olein is due to the lower melting point of the unsaponifiable fraction. It contributes to the super olein potential to be used as salad oil. The higher distribution of carotenoids to the light

phase is also observed in the palm oil fractionation. After the first fractionation, the palm olein usually presents 10 to 20% higher concentration of carotenoids than the original oil. After three more fractionation stages, it is possible to obtain an olein ( called top olein) which may contain up to twice the carotenoid concentration compared with the original oil (May, 1994; Kellens et al., 2007) .

The FA composition also influences the nutritional quality of the edible oil , there is a concern about the ingestion of food with a high concentration of saturated FAs , these compounds are associ ated with an increase of the LDL in the blood, and, therefore, increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases (DiNicolantonio & O’Keefe, 2018) . The FA profile of the tucuma olein, super olein and mid -fraction is presented in Table 5. As can be observed, oleic a cid is the major FA in tucuma olein (65. 4%), being a source of monounsaturated FA with high oxidative stability and human health functionality, such as immunomodulation and prevention of developing cancer and cardiovascular disease (O’ Brien, 2004; Sales -Campos e t al., 2013) . Moreover, it has polyunsaturated FAs (7.29%) and low content of saturated FAs (27.4%) supporting its potential use for salad oil and to formulate foods with low saturated fat. Table 5. The fatty acid profile of tucuma pulp olein, super olein and mid -fraction obtained by natural fractionation.

Fatty acids (%) Olein Super Olein Tucuma mid - fraction Monounsaturated 65.4 67.0 64.9 Polyunsaturated 7.29 7.66 6.83 Different letters on the same line represent significantly different values (p<0.05). The presence of FA with a high melting point in tucuma olein, such as palmitic (22.2%) and stearic (5.19%), favored natural crystallization. Besides, there was a significant difference in the composition of FA after fractionation of tucuma olein. The conte nt of mono and polyunsaturated FA was significantly higher in super olein than in the tucuma

mid-fraction. The latter, as expected, presented higher content of saturated FA. Compared with olein, super olein presented an increase of about 2.1% of the IV, wh ile the tucuma mid-fraction showed a decrease of about 1.3%. However, oleic acid was the major FA in both fractions, ensuring structured lipids with low saturated fat content despite the difference in FA composition. The FA composition for the tucuma olein was similar to that reported by Santos et al. (2013a) for the tucuma oil, despite the lower stearic content and the absence of mangiferic acid.

The results shown in Table 5 for tucuma olein differ from the data reported for palm oil (51 - 53 IV). The first palm fractionation generates a palm olein with 56 -59 IV and palm stearin 22 - 49 IV. The palm olein fractionation generates a palm mid -fractio n and palm super olein with 42 - 48 and 60 - 66 IV, respectively. Therefore, the fractionation of FA is more pronounced in palm oil, resulting in super olein with an increase of up to 10% of unsaturated FA. In contrast, palm mid -fraction presents an increa se of up to 17% in saturated FA. Therefore, regarding the use as salad oil, tucuma super olein offers health benefits compared to palm super olein since it shows higher unsaturated FA composition (IV 74 and 60 - 66, respectively) (Gunstone, 2002; Kellens et al., 2007) . Moreover, the tucuma mid -fraction may have potential as a substitute for palm oil fractions and hydrogenated vegetable oils, with nutritional advantages as they have a much lower conten t of saturated FA, i.e., about 29% in tucuma mid -fraction and 50% in palm mid - fraction (Gunstone, 2002; Kellens et al., 2007; McClements & Decker, 2017) . According to FA composition, the functional quality of olein, super olein and the mid - fraction was calculated (Table 6). Based on the literature fo r palm oil (Gunstone, 2002) , these values were also calculated for olein, super olein, and palm mid -fraction for comparison (Table 6).

Functional quality of lipid fractions Tucuma Palm Olein Super Olein Tucuma mid- fraction Olein Super olein Palm mid- fraction H/H: hypocholesterolemic and hypercholesterolemic FAs; AI: atherogenicity index; TI: thrombogenicity index.
The H/H ratio should be high since saturated FA are associated with an increase in LDL concentration. In contrast, unsaturated FA are associated with a decrease in LDL levels.

Low-density lipoproteins transport cholesterol from the liver to cells, while HDL trans port it to the liver, where it is metabolized and excreted. Thus, the increase in LDL levels is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (Damodaran et al., 2010; DiNicolantonio & O’Keefe, 2018) . As expected, all the tucuma lipid fractions had a higher H/H value than the palm fractions.

The atherogenicity index ( AI) and the thrombogenicity index ( TI) are related to the propensity for coronary heart disease. Therefore, the lower the value of these ind exes, the greater the amount of antiatherogenic FA that inhibit platelet aggregation and, consequently, increase the potential for preventing coronary heart disease (Ulbright & Southgate, 1991; Turan et al., 2007) . All analyzed fractions of oil from tucuma pulp meet this requirement; however, only the AI of palm olein and palm super olein has a value of less than 1. These results confirm the functional benefits of replacing the lipid fractions of palm with tucu ma since this oil has a composition of FA that reduces the risk of developing cardiovascular disease.

Olein and its fractions have mostly TAG with 52 and 54 carbon atoms, predominately di - unsaturated and fully unsaturated TAG. There was no significant difference in the content of these TAG in the fractionation of olein fr om tucuma. However, as expected, the mid - fraction showed a higher content of TAG with 48 (PPP) and 50 (POP) carbon atoms that have a high melting point. The greater amount of these TAG, formed mainly by palmitic fatty acid, corroborates the FA analysis tha t showed a greater amount of this FA in the mid fraction.

The peaks corresponding to TAG with 52 carbon atoms show a greater abundance of fragmentation ions with m/z of 577, 339 and 265 (corresponding to the FA O and [PO]+ ions), possibly indicating a grea ter abundance of TAG as POO. The peak corresponding to the TAG with 54 carbon atoms has a greater abundance of ions with m/z of 603, corresponding to the [OO]+ ion, 339 and 265, possibly indicating greater abundance of OOO. This observation corroborates th e FA analysis with P and O FAs as the major species.

The TAG and FA analysis of the tucuma olein explain the potential oil fractionation since palmitic and stearic FAs have a high melting temperature (62.9 °C and 69.6 °C, respectively) and are easily cryst allized. The POP also has a high melting temperature in the β' configuration (about 30 -35 °C), contributing to the olein crystallization. However, the major TAG of tucuma olein (POO) has a melting temperature in the β' configuration similar to the olein fr actionation range temperature (11.7 °C and 9 -13 °C, respectively), while OOO has a melting temperature of -12 °C in the β’ configuration (Sato, 2001; Gunstone, 200 2).

Calliauw et al. (2010) studie d the growth behavior of refined palm olein crystals with different concentrations of the fully saturated TAG PPP and found that at 15 °C, the increase in solid fat content as a function of time was promoted at higher concentrations of PPP. Furthermore, sp ecific interactions between PPP and POP indicate that PPP promotes POP crystallisation, where the first initial PPP crystals serve as a β' model for POP crystallisation. These two TAG form a solid solution with a relatively high melting point in its β' for m, possibly stabilized by the presence of POP under specific conditions of palm olein fractionation (Calliauw et al., 2010; Vereecken et al., 2010) . In palm oil, there is a preferential migration of TAG with ACN 48 to stearin concerning olein in the first fractionation. This fact is also observed in the second fractionation, where olein with a content of 2.4 - 3.9% of TAG with ACN 48 generates a super olein with a content of 1.7 - 2.6% and a mid -fraction with a content of 1.4 - 11.3% of this TAG. In the second fractionation of the palm oil, a preferential migration of TAG with ACN 50 to the mid-fraction and of TAG with ACN 52 and 54 to super olein is al so observed (Gunstone, 2002) . Such observation is not seen in the fractionation of tucuma oil, which corroborates the generation of a fraction rich in structured lipids and unsaturat ed FAs. The presence of different species of TAG helped promote the fractionation and formation of the pseudo -β' type polymorph since systems that present a heterogeneous mixture of
TAG are more likely to form a β' type polymorph (Oboh & Oderinde, 1988; Vereecken
4. Conclusions

The tucuma olein was efficient in forming a solid phase rich in structured lipids with a pseudoplastic fluid behavior, pseudo -β' type crystals stable at room temperature, low saturated FA (less than 30%) and fully saturated triacylglycerols content desired for industrial food manufacture. Thus, tucuma super olein presents a potential for use as salad oil since it contains, in addition to carotenoids, mono and polyunsaturated fat ty acids and fully unsaturated TAG. In turn, the tucuma mid -fraction presents a high content of monounsaturated fatty acids and diunsaturated and fully unsaturated triacylglycerols. It could be used advantageously in the manufacture of foods rich in struct ured lipids, such as margarine and shortenings, with health benefits compared with palm oil fractions, traditionally used to replace hydrogenated fats worldwide.

CAPÍTULO 4
Análise de compostos voláteis do óleo de tucumã ( Astrocaryum vulgare Mart.) e suas frações
Maria Fernanda S. Motaa, Meire Jéssica A. Ferreiraa, Claudia Moraes de Rezendeb e Suely P. Freitasa

aUniversidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Escola de Química, Av. Athos da Silveira Ramos, 149 - Bloco E - Cidade Universitária, Rio de Janeiro - RJ, bUniversidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Instituto de Química, Labo ratório de Análise de Aromas, Av. Athos da Silveira Ramos, 149 - Bloco A, 6º andar, Sala 626A - Cidade Universitária, Rio de Janeiro - RJ, 21044 -020, Brasil
Artigo em elaboração para publicação
Resumo:

O objetivo desse trabalho foi analisar e identificar os compostos voláteis presentes no óleo obtido da polpa do tucumã e das suas frações (oleína e estearina) obtidas por cristalização natural. O tucumã ( Astrocaryum vulgare Mart.) é uma palmeira nativa da América do Sul que apresenta alta concent ração de lipídios em sua polpa, de onde se extraí um óleo rico em carotenoides. Atualmente, o óleo de tucumã não refinado é utilizado em culinária e para fins cosméticos, se destacando pela sua coloração alaranjada e seu aroma único. O sabor delicado do ól eo da polpa de tucumã pode ser atribuído aos seus compostos voláteis, muitos dos quais se desenvolvem a partir dos carotenoides presentes no fruto. O óleo de tucumã e suas frações apresentaram predominância de monoterpenos (45 -50%), sendo o linalol o de ma ior proporção ( 65-87%). Na análise comparativa entre as frações, a oleína apresentou um maior número de compostos voláteis (total de 24). A semi -quantificação da oleína apresentou 22 compostos a mais se comparados aos detectados na análise comparativa prév ia, sendo 8 provenientes de reações de oxidação lipídica. A oleína de tucumã apresentou predominância de compostos com aroma doce, frutado e floral com potencial de aplicação na indústria de alimentos e cosmética para valorização sensorial dos produtos der ivados.
Palavras -chave: aroma, Amazônia, fruta nativa, óleos vegetais.
1. Introdução

Os compostos orgânicos voláteis respondem pelo aroma característico de óleos vegetais não refinados e seu estudo ainda representa um grande desafio analítico . Estes compostos são oriundos de rotas biossintéticas variadas e ainda , de reações que ocorrem durante seu processamento, como a oxidação dos ácidos graxos, bem como da interação de compostos carbonilados com moléculas nitrogenadas (DAMODARAN; PARKIN e FENNEMA, 2010). A oxidação lipídica consiste em uma sequência de reações químicas resultantes da ação do oxigênio sobre os óleos vegetais. Ela é autocatalítica e geralmente apresenta uma fase lag seguida de um aumento exponencial das taxas de oxidação. Essas reações geram moléculas voláteis tais como os aldeídos e cetonas, normalmente indesejáveis nos óleos vegetais. Os ácidos graxos poli -insaturados estão potencialmente sujeitos à oxidação

lipídica, cujos produtos são responsáveis pela diminuição das propriedades nu tricionais e sensoriais dos óleos (DAMODARAN; PARKIN e FENNEMA, 2010) . Portanto, a caracterização da fração volátil dos óleos comestíveis é uma ferramenta clássica para a avaliação dos compostos de aroma presentes e no estudo da degradação de óleos comestíveis (DAMODARAN; PARKIN e FENNEMA, 2010).

O perfil volátil é em parte responsável pelos atributos sensoriais que influenciam na apreciação do óleo pelos consumidores. Óleos considerados “gourmets” , em particular o azeite de oliva extravirgem , não são submetidos ao refino com vistas a preservar os compostos de aroma, além de outros índices de qualidade. O aroma típico do óleo de oliva é atribuído a aldeídos, cetonas, álcoois, ésteres, furanos e hidrocarbonetos. Os principais compostos que contribuem para o atributo sensorial de frutado, pungente e amargo do azeite incluem o h exanal, ( E)-hex-2-enal, hexan -1-ol e 3 -metilbutan -1-ol (KALUA et al., A presença e abundância dos compostos voláteis de origem vegetal depende m do grau de maturação do fruto e/ou podem ser formados durante o processamento e degra dação do óleo (SANAHUJA et al., 2011; YUAN e QIAN, 2016; JIA et al., 2018; XU et al., 2019; CECCHI et al ., 2020; ZHANG, CAO e LIU, 2020). Uma grande diversidade de compostos de aroma é também derivada dos carotenoides. Os norisoprenoides podem ser produzid os por clivagem enzimática ou não enzimática de carotenoides. (WINTERHALTER & ROUSSEFF, 2001; UENOJO et al., 2007; WINTERHALTER e A formação dos norisoprenoides depende do carotenoide precursor e da posição onde ocorre a clivagem da cadeia carbônica (WINTERHALTER e ROUSSEFF, 2001; RODRÍGUEZ -BUSTAMANTE e SÁNCHEZ, 2007). Dentre os principais compostos de aroma derivados dos carotenoides, podemos destacar iononas e damasconas, que possuem o esqueleto carbônico das megastigmanas. A diferença est rutural entre as iononas e damasconas está na posição da função contendo oxigênio, localizada no carbono 9 na família das iononas e no carbono 7 na família das damasconas (Figura 1). Além destes, voláteis derivados de carotenoides contendo 9, 10 e 11 átomo s de carbono também são frequentemente detectados na natureza, tais como o isoforona, safranal e di -
idroactinidiolida, respectivamente (WINTERHALTER e ROUSSEFF, 2001; RODRÍGUEZ -BUSTAMANTE e SÁNCHEZ, 2007).

carotenoides (adaptado de WINTERHALTER e ROUSSEFF, 2001) . Os compostos de aroma derivados de carotenoides já foram detectados no tabaco, chá, mate, em óleos essenciais, frutas, vegetais, flores, vinho, rum, café, mel, algas, óleo de palma, entre outros. Os norisoprenoides costumam apresentar um limiar de detecção de odor baixo e são importantes para a formação da fragrância de muitos alimentos, apesar de normalmente estarem presentes em reduzida concentração (DIRINCK et al., 1977; WINTERHALTER e ROUSSEFF, 2001; UENOJO et al ., 2007; MENDES -PINTO, 2009; WINTERHALTER e EBELER, 2013). Muitos compostos voláteis são produzidos em tecidos vegetais em estágios específicos de desenvolvimento como, por exemplo, durante a floração, o amadurecimento ou a maturação, atuando como dispersores de sementes. Outros compostos voláte is, por sua vez, auxiliam animais e seres humanos a reconhecer quando o fruto não está mais apropriado para consumo (GUFF e KLEE, 2006; S CHWAB, DAVIDOVICH - Di-hidroactinidiolida Safranal Isoforonaβ-ionona β-damascona

RIKANATI e LEWINSOHN, 2008) . No caso dos humanos, aromas como a geranilacetona, β -ionona e 6 -metil -5-hepten -2-ona podem indicar a presença de compostos que apresentam ação antimicrobiológica, antioxidante, anticarcinogênica. Além disso , a β -ionona, α -ionona, di -hidroactinidiolida, damascenol e β -ciclocitral também apresentam função antifúngica (SIMKIN et al., 2004; UENOJO, MARÓSTICA JUNIOR e PASTORE, 2007; SCHWAB, DAVIDOVICH -RIKANATI e LEWINSOHN, A microextração em fase sólida ( MEFS) é a técnica mais popular para a amostragem de frações voláteis de óleos comestíveis (TINOCO et al. , 2016; BRILHANTE et al., 2020) . Essa técnica é isenta de solventes e se baseia no fenômeno de adsorção dos compostos presentes no headspace da amostra pela fibra de MEFS (bastão de fibra ótica de sílica fundida que tem uma extremidade recoberta por um filme fino de um polímero – material sorvente) e posterior dessorção dos mesmos no injetor do cromatógrafo. Temperatura, velocidade de agitação e tempo de extração são parâmetros relevantes que podem alterar a composição do headspace da amostra e ocasionam variações na capacidade de extração e eficiência da fibra para alguns compostos (PEÑA et al., 2005; TINOCO et al., 2016). A análise de volátei s por MEFS -CG-EM e MEFS -CG-DIC é amplamente utilizada para a avaliação dos compostos voláteis em óleos vegetais, sendo a primeira técnica mais utilizada para a identificação dos compostos basead a na sua razão massa/carga ( m/z) e perfil de fragmentação; e a segunda é mais utilizada para quantificação e semi - quantificação devido à alta sensibilidade do detector de ionização em chama e a respostas mais lineares entre os compostos presentes nestas matrizes. A semi -quantificação de compostos voláteis por MEFS -CG-DIC é geralmente realizada pela adição de um padrão interno ( RUIZ -HERNÁNDEZ et al., 2018; GIUFFRÈ et al., 2020; BRILHANTE et al., O tucumã ( Astrocaryum vulgare Mart.) é uma palmeira nativa da América do Sul que apresenta alta concentração de lipíd ios tanto na sua polpa (41 a 74%) quanto n o endocarpo (40%) (LIMA, TRASSATO e COELHO, 1986; MAMBRIN e BARRERA ARELLANO, 1997; SHANLEY e MEDINA, 2005; FERREIRA et al., 2008).

O perfil de voláteis do extrato da polpa e da casca do fruto do tucumã ( Astrocary um vulgare Mart.), obtidos por hidrodestilação com n-pentano, foi analisado por CG -EM. Vinte e seis compostos voláteis foram descritos, majoritariamente ésteres, sendo o

hexanoato de etila o mais abundante (47,5%), seguido do butanoato de etila (9,0%) e do octanoato de etila (4,1%). Apenas um composto volátil, a β -ionona (0,5%), derivado de carotenoides foi descrito no aroma do fruto do tucumã (ANDRADE et al, 1998). O óleo extraído da polpa do tucumã apresenta uma grande quantidade de ácidos graxos monoins aturados (46 – 68%) e compostos antioxidantes, se destacando pelo seu alto teor de carotenoides totais, majoritariamente β -caroteno (CHIU et al., 2009; COIMBRA e JORGE, SANTOS et al ., 2013b; SANTOS, ALVES e ROCA, 2015). A composição química do óleo de tucu mã revela suas características nutricional, funcional e sensorial , sendo fonte de compostos importantes para a saúde humana (MAMBRIM e BARRERA - ARELLANO, 1997; SANTOS et al., 2013a).

O fracionamento natural do óleo do tucumã pode ser realizado pelo processo de cristalização, possibilitando a separação de uma fração líquida (denominada oleína) e uma fração semissólida a temperatura ambiente (25 ± 5 °C, denominada estearina), que também podem ser fracionadas possibilitando desenvolvimento de uma cadeia produti va de subprodutos do óleo de tucumã. O fracionamento é um processo físico reversível de modificação de óleos que tem como finalidade separar o óleo original em duas ou mais frações com propriedades físicas e/ou químicas diferentes ampliando suas aplicações industriais (KELLENS et al., 2007). Atualmente, o óleo extraído da polpa do tucumã é utilizado na forma não refinada e é utilizado em culinária e para fins cosméticos. Esse óleo se destaca pela sua coloração alaranjada e seu aroma único, entretanto são ra ros os estudos reportados na literatura referentes à identificação de seus componentes voláteis. Neste contexto, o objetivo desse trabalho foi analisar e identificar, pelo método de MEFS, os compostos voláteis presentes no óleo obtido da polpa do tucumã e nas suas frações obtidas por cristalização natural.
2. Metodologia
2.1. Extração

Frutos da palmeira de tucumã do Pará ( Astrocaryum vulgare Mart.) procedentes do município de Irituia, localizado no estado do Pará – Brasil foram coletados no mês de fevereiro/2020 , que corresponde ao período de frutificação. O transporte foi feito em sacos de polietileno até o laboratório de Lipídios e Derivados, da Escola de Química – UFRJ, onde os frutos foram armazenados sob refrigeração em 4ºC e, posteriormente,

processados. O processamento dos frutos de tucumã obedeceu às seguintes etapas: seleção de frutos sadios, sem defeitos e que não estivessem em grau de maturação avançado; lavagem; despolpamento manual ; autoclavagem da polpa a 121 °C por 30 min para a inativação das lipases endógenas ; acondicionamento em embalagem plástica de polietileno e armazenamento sob refrigeração em 4ºC.

Para a extração do óleo da polpa do tucumã, as porções do epicarpo e mesocarpo foram distribuídas em bandejas para seca gem em estufa com circulação forçada de ar a 40 °C, durante 24 horas, resultando em uma polpa com umidade entre 5 e 10%. Após secagem, a polpa foi triturada e o óleo foi extraído por prensagem em prensa contínua do tipo rosca sem fim ( expeller ), modelo CA 59 O (IBG Monforts, Mönchengladbach, Alemanha) a 25 ± 2 °C com velocidade do parafuso de 30 rpm e diâmetro de saída da matriz da prensa de 8 mm. O óleo extraído foi filtrado, fracionado e armazenado sob refrigeração a -4º C.
2.2. Fracionamento

O fracionament o natural do óleo de tucumã foi realizado na temperatura ambiente (25 ± 5 °C) por 2 semanas em repouso e protegido da luz. A separação de fases foi realizada por centrifugação a 5000 rpm por 10 min. As fases separadas foram armazenadas sob refrigeração a -4 ºC.
2.3. Teor de carotenoides

A quantificação dos carotenoides totais no óleo e nas frações obtidas foi determinada por espectrofotometria (Bel SP1105, Bel Engineering, Monza, Itália); a amostra foi diluída com éter de petróleo e a absorbância a 450 nm foi u tilizada para o cálculo dos carotenoides totais de acordo com a equação 1 (RODRIGUEZ -AMAYA, 2016). A análise foi feita em triplicata.
onde ABS representa o valor da absorbâ ncia a 450 nm, V o volume da amostra e M a massa da amostra em gramas.
2.4. Identificação dos compostos voláteis presentes no óleo, oleína e estearina de tucumã
2.4.1. Microextração em Fase Sólida (MEFS)

A análise de voláteis do óleo, oleína e estearina do tucumã fo i realizada por Microextração em Fase Sólida (MEFS) com base em condições otimizadas por Tinoco et al. (2016), com modificações. A fibra composta de Divinilbenzeno/Carboxeno em Polidimetilsiloxano (DVB/CAR/PDMS) previamente acondicionada por 60 minutos no injetor do cromatógrafo gasoso a 250 °C. A extração foi realizada em frasco de 4 mL contendo 0,500 ± 0,005 g da amostra e 50 µL do padrão interno ( n-pentadecano 0,1 mg /mL em hexano). A temperatura de extração foi de 40 ± 5°C. O tempo de condicionamento da amostra na temperatura de extração foi de 30 minutos e o tempo de exposição da fibra no headspace do frasco foi de 30 minutos. Após o tempo de extração, a fibra foi recolhida dentro da seringa e imediatamente exposta no injetor do cromatógrafo a gás perman ecendo por 5 minutos para dessorção térmica dos compostos voláteis. 2.4.2. Análise em Cromatografia Gasosa acoplad a ao Espectrômetro de Massas As análises foram realizadas utilizando um cromatógrafo a gás acoplado ao espectrômetro de massas (CG -qEM) da marca Agi lent (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA), modelo 6850 para CG e 5975C para o qEM, com coluna DB -5 (30 m; 0,25 mm; 0,25 μm; Agilent J&W, Santa Clara, CA). As condições cromatográficas utilizadas foram similares ao descrito por Adams (2017), fluxo d o gás de arraste hélio de 1,0 ml min-1 com modo de injeção splitless e liner sem lã de vidro, temperaturas do injetor de 250 °C, da fonte de 230 °C, do quadrupolo de 150 °C e da linha de transferência de 280 °C. A temperatura inicial do forno foi de 60 °C com programação de 3 °C min-1 até 150 °C, posteriormente a temperatura do forno aumentou a uma taxa de 20 °C min-1 até 250 °C para limpeza da coluna. Foi utilizado modo de varredura de íons ( scan) m/z 50 – 550 e captura de sinal após 3 minutos da injeção. A análise foi feita em triplicata.

Uma mistura padrão de n-alcanos (Sigma -Aldrich C7 -C40) diluída 1:10 em hexano foi utilizada para calcular o índice de retenção linear (IRL) de cada substância na amostra pela Equação 1. A comparação do IRL das substâncias calculado com os dados da literatura (ADAMS, 2007; NIST, 2014), a análise do espectro de massas e o banco de
dados da espectroteca NIST 2.2 2014 foram utilizados para tentativa de identificação das substâncias detectadas.

onde 𝑡𝑅(𝑥) é o tempo de retenção do composto de interesse, 𝑡𝑅(𝐴𝑧) é o tempo de retenção do n-alcano anterior ao composto de interesse, 𝑡𝑅(𝐴𝑧+1) é o tempo de retenção do n- alcano anterior e 𝐴𝑧 o número de carbon os do n-alcano anterior. 2.5. Semi -quantificação dos compostos voláteis da oleína A semi -quantificação dos compostos voláteis da oleína foi realizada utilizando condições de MEFS similares à utilizada na análise de MEFS -CG-EM, diferindo pela utilização de 10 µL de uma solução de n-pentadecano a 4,79 mg/g em óleo de girassol refinado como padrão interno e da adição de agitação com barra magnética. O óleo de girassol foi escolhido para compensar os efeitos da matriz e a agitação foi adicionada para garantir uma maior taxa de transferência de massa da fase líquida para o headspace (RUIZ -HERNÁNDEZ et al., 2018; BRILHANTE et al., 2022).

As análises de semi -quantificação foram realizadas utilizando um cromatógrafo a gás equipado com detector de ionização em chama (C G-DIC) da marca Agilent modelo 6890N, com coluna DB -5 (30 m; 0,25 mm; 0,25 μm). As condições cromatográficas utilizadas foram similares à utilizada na análise de espectrometria de massas. A análise foi feita em triplicata. A tentativa de identificação das substâncias presentes foi realizada pelo cálculo do IRL de cada substância e análise em CG -EM conforme descritos no
2.6. Análise estatística
As análises estatísticas foram realizadas por meio do teste de comparação de médias (Fisher -LSD), consi derando um intervalo de confiança de 95% (p <0,05).
3. Resultados
3.1. Fracionamento e carotenoides totais
O fracionamento do óleo do tucumã resultou em uma relação oleína/estearina: 2,5 m/m, essa relação foi obtida após 2 semanas a temperatura ambiente. Esse tem po de
fracionamento foi necessário para visualização nítida de duas fases, conforme ilustrado na Figura 2. A fase superior é, tradicionalmente, denominada oleína e a inferior estearina.
O óleo da polpa de tucumã apresentou um teor de carotenoides totais entre 1012 e 1210 μg/g. Não foi observada diferença significativa no teor de carotenoide totais entre o óleo , oleína e estearina .

O óleo de tucumã e suas frações apresentaram teor de carotenoides similar aos reportados na literatura para o óleo de tucumã (cerca de 1200 μg/g) e superior aos valores reportados para o óleo de palma (474 a 689 μg/g) e para o óleo de buriti (cerca de 540 μg/g) (SANTOS et al., 2015; DEPARTMENT OF STANDARDS MALAYSIA, 2007a,b). De acordo com Santos et al. (2015), os principais carotenoides presentes no óleo de tucumã em μg/g são: o β-caroteno (~ 565); cis β-caroteno (~ 230); neoxantina (~ 75); cis γ caroteno O alto teor de carotenoides do óleo de tucumã e suas frações contribuem para o seu expressivo potencial nutricional, uma vez que esses compostos são antioxidantes com benefícios no tratamento de doenças crônico -degenerativas e cardiovasculares, diabetes, neurodegeneração, catarata e degeneração macular (RODRIGUEZ -AMAYA, 2016). Além disso, c arotenoides que possuem estrutura cíclica e anel β, tais como o β -caroteno, apresentam atividade como precursores de vitamina A, cuja deficiência é um dos principais problemas nutricionais nas regiões menos desenvolvidas do mundo (WHO, 2009; RIBEIRO, BARRETO e COELHO, 2011; QUEIROZ et al., 2013). Além disso, os carotenoides são precursores de compostos de aroma important es para a formação de sabor de diversos alimentos (UENOJO et al., 2007).
Oleína de tucumã Estearina de tucumã

3.2. Comparação entre os compostos voláteis identificados no óleo, oleína e estearina de tucumã O cromatograma obtido por MEFS por CG -EM do óleo de tucumã e suas frações está apresentado na Figura 3. O perfil se apresentou bastante similar, a estearina com um total de 19 compostos os quais também estão presentes no óleo e na oleína. O óleo apresentou 22 compostos voláteis, diferindo da estearina por apresentar o ó xido de linalila, terpino leno e 2,6 -dimetil -1,3,5,7 -octatetraeno. A oleína foi a fração que exibiu o maior número de compostos voláteis, apresentando os 22 compostos identificados para o óleo de tucumã e ainda α-cubebeno e a trans -geranilacetona.

(C) oleína de tucumã. Os números de 1 a 24 correspondem aos compostos identificados na Tabela 1, PI corresponde ao padrão interno. A maior abundância de compostos voláteis foi observada na oleína. Esta fração, em geral, apresenta menor viscosidade se comparada com a viscosidade do óleo e da estearina como constatado por Abdul Azis et al. (2011) para o óleo de palma fracionado. A visc osidade de óleos vegetais é fortemente dependente do tamanho da cadeia e do número de

insaturações, sendo significativamente menor em matrizes mais insaturadas. Quanto menor a viscosidade do meio, maior a taxa de difusão dos componentes voláteis para a superfície e maior a transferência destes compostos para a fase gás e, consequentemente, para o headspace da análise de MEFS. Como esperado, a menor abundância observada na estearina se deve à sua maior viscosidade se comparada às demais frações. Estes resul tados, provavelmente, explicam a não detecção no óleo e na estearina de alguns compostos voláteis minoritários identificados apenas na oleína. A Tabela 1 apresenta os compostos voláteis identificados por CG -EM no óleo de tucumã e em suas frações obtidas por fracionamento natural. Dentre os 24 compostos voláteis identificados na oleína, todos tiveram sua identidade confirmada pelo IRL apresentado em Adams (2007) ou na NIST
